content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Accepted because it is very original and fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A few things to note:

1) 5DN1L suggested "Let there be a right triangle with sides ..."
You wrote "Let there be a right triangle with side ..."

2) Stub generator code could be better, for example:

read c:word(3) cb:word(3)
write a b h

3) Maybe give people some suggestions on "other formulas of your choice"? For example, you can suggest looking for Pythagorean theorem.

Except these notices, I think it is a very nice puzzle.

"Input: Space separated string containg *2 positive integers*..." Why is there a test case where the integers... aren't integers? Also, if there's a constraint for [[c]], there should also be a constraint for [[cb]], don't you think?

And if the programmer needs to check validity of inputs anyway, then why are there even constraints? There could be a test case where an input is 0 or negative.

Otherwise, it's a very cool contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This checks member's math knowledge and language methods.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I've read the statement a few times, and cannot understand it until I look up Wikipedia.

* Every triangle has three heights.
* To me, <<c>> and [[c]] denote side c and length of side c respectively and are not the same thing.

Based on the above two points, and making a few other changes as well, I would suggest to change the statement as follows:

Let there be a right triangle with sides <<a>>, <<b>> and <<c>>, where <<c>> is the hypotenuse. <<h>> is the height drawn from the right angle to <<c>>, and splits <<c>> to <<ca>> (the segment connected to <<a>>) and <<cb>> (the segment connected to <<b>>).

As Euclid stated, when given the hypotenuse length [[c]] and the length of one of the hypotenuse segments [[cb]], it is possible to determine the length of all sides and of the height, by using this formula:
[[h]]² = [[ca]] * [[cb]]

Other comments

Goal section
* Suggest to format "INCORRECT" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks. Please also add "." at the end of the sentence.

* Please change "2 decimals" to "2 decimal places".

Input section
* Please add "positive integers or strings" to denote the possible variable types.

* Please add descriptions to the variables, e.g. "for the lengths of <<c>> and <<cb>> respectively".

Output section
* Please change "length" to "lengths".

* Please mention that the lengths should be space-separated.

* Please mention "or {{INCORRECT}}".

Constraints section
* Suggest to change ≤ to < because it is unclear how the cases where c = 0 should be handled.

Thanks.
Thank you, all very valid suggestions, I will change accordingly.

thank you for your input, however I believe you didn't read the whole Input statement:


Input
Space separated string containing 2 positive integers describing the lengths of the side c c and the segment cb cb , or strings whenever wrong data is present.

About the test case, of course there could be more test cases, and thank you for the suggestions. There is 1 test case and relative validator where [[cb]] is bigger than [[c]], which already proves the point I believe. In the IDE you can always create custom test cases if you want to test different situations.
thank you for the approval and for the suggestions, much appreciated.
Okay. I'll approve it. (When I have time to test it)

Thank you. There are two comments that still need to be followed up:

Input section
* Please change "integers" to "positive integers or strings" to denote the possible variable types (or alternatively, remove the last pair of cases).

Output section
* Please mention "or {{INCORRECT}}".

Thanks again.
